Patcharee Boonruangrod $:$ Durian Dieback Caused by Fusarium solani and Fungicide Control. Master of Science (Plant Pathology), Major Field: Plant Pathology, Department of Plant Pathology.   
Thesis Advisor: Associate Professor Ratiya Pongpisutta, Ph.D.   
Academic Year 2020

text.text_translated:
Patcharee Boonruangrod $:$ Durian Dieback Caused by Fusarium solani and Fungicide Control. Master of Science (Plant Pathology), Major Field: Plant Pathology, Department of Plant Pathology.   
Thesis Advisor: Associate Professor Ratiya Pongpisutta, Ph.D.   
Academic Year 2020 

Four isolates of fungal pathogens such as TRA006, TRA020, CHA032 and CHA040 collected from durian plantations in Trat and Chanthaburi provinces were investigated. Identification based on morphology and DNA markers by PCR techniques at ITS region and TEF1-gene alpha using ITS4/ITS5 and ef1/ef2 primer pairs was classified as Fusarium solani. Physiological factors were examined. The results showed that the fungal mycelia, 4 isolates grew very well on different culture media. It was found that TRA006 and TRA020 thrived on SNA $^ +$ carnation leaves SNA and Kerr's $^ +$ carnation leaves while CHA032 and CHA040 were on PDA+ carnation leaves. Growth temperature at $2 5 { - } 3 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ on medium with $\mathrm { p H } \ 6 { - } 7$ and incubated in the dark for $2 4 ~ \mathrm { { h r } }$ . were optimum conditions for mycelial growth of. $F$ solani. Sporulation was studied, there was no correlation between the appropriate media with large amounts of macroconidia and microconidia, excluding TRA020, which was found the greatest number both types of spore production on PDA. Nevertheless, all isolates showed highly spore-forming at $2 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ on medium with pH 6-7 and incubated under alternation of 12hr near UV light/dark. Pathogenicity assay of $F .$ solani were tested on some parts of 6- month-old durian seedlings. CHA040 presented the most severe strain, it was selected to use for this study. Wound inoculation showed disease symptom on the branches, leaves, flowers and roots. Whilst unwound inoculation displayed the symptom all parts mentioned above except leaves.
text.text:
Patcharee Boonruangrod $:$ Durian Dieback Caused by Fusarium solani and Fungicide Control. Master of Science (Plant Pathology), Major Field: Plant Pathology, Department of Plant Pathology.   
Thesis Advisor: Associate Professor Ratiya Pongpisutta, Ph.D.   
Academic Year 2020 

Four isolates of fungal pathogens such as TRA006, TRA020, CHA032 and CHA040 collected from durian plantations in Trat and Chanthaburi provinces were investigated. Identification based on morphology and DNA markers by PCR techniques at ITS region and TEF1-gene alpha using ITS4/ITS5 and ef1/ef2 primer pairs was classified as Fusarium solani. Physiological factors were examined. The results showed that the fungal mycelia, 4 isolates grew very well on different culture media. It was found that TRA006 and TRA020 thrived on SNA $^ +$ carnation leaves SNA and Kerr's $^ +$ carnation leaves while CHA032 and CHA040 were on PDA+ carnation leaves. Growth temperature at $2 5 { - } 3 0 ~ ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ on medium with $\mathrm { p H } \ 6 { - } 7$ and incubated in the dark for $2 4 ~ \mathrm { { h r } }$ . were optimum conditions for mycelial growth of. $F$ solani. Sporulation was studied, there was no correlation between the appropriate media with large amounts of macroconidia and microconidia, excluding TRA020, which was found the greatest number both types of spore production on PDA. Nevertheless, all isolates showed highly spore-forming at $2 5 ^ { \circ } \mathrm { C }$ on medium with pH 6-7 and incubated under alternation of 12hr near UV light/dark. Pathogenicity assay of $F .$ solani were tested on some parts of 6- month-old durian seedlings. CHA040 presented the most severe strain, it was selected to use for this study. Wound inoculation showed disease symptom on the branches, leaves, flowers and roots. Whilst unwound inoculation displayed the symptom all parts mentioned above except leaves.

text.text_translated:
CHA040 presented the most severe strain, it was selected to use for this study. Wound inoculation showed disease symptom on the branches, leaves, flowers and roots. Whilst unwound inoculation displayed the symptom all parts mentioned above except leaves. 

The efficacy of six fungicides such as carbendazim, copper hydroxide, hymexazol, metalaxyl, phosphonic acid and pyraclostrobin controlling. $F .$ solani in vitro was evaluated. Carbendazim at the. concentrations of $6 2 . 5 \mathrm { p p m }$ and above showed the best efficiency inhibiting mycelial growth after 7 days of incubation period. Moreover, there was consistent results in the greenhouse test using $5 0 0 \mathrm { p p m }$ (recommended rate) carbendazim spray outcoming $6 9 \%$ effective in disease controlling after 30 days of chemical spraying.

This table, attributed to Baharuddin (2001), details the relationship between various species of the Fusarium fungus, the plants they infect, and the diseases they cause. The data is organized into three columns: 'Fusarium' lists the fungal species, 'Plants' identifies the host, and 'Diseases' describes the resulting condition. Several species of Fusarium are listed, with some plants being affected by multiple types. For example, asparagus is affected by both F. oxysporum and F. proliferatum, which cause wilt, crown, and root rot. Similarly, F. oxysporum and F. solani cause 'slanting death' in tea. The F. oxysporum species is shown to infect a wide variety of plants including bananas, tea, watermelon, passion fruit, and coffee, causing various types of wilt. Other specific pairings include F. sacchari causing 'pokkah boeng' in cane and F. fujikuroi causing 'bakanae' in rice. The table notes that unspecified Fusarium species ('Fusarium spp.') are responsible for rot in corn and pineapple. The entry for roselle is spread across multiple rows, indicating that F. oxysporum f. sp. rosellae, F. solani, and other Fusarium species cause wilt and root rot. Overall, the table illustrates that the Fusarium genus of fungi is a pathogen responsible for a wide range of diseases in numerous important plant species.

The table compares three historical classification systems for what appears to be the Fusarium genus, as proposed by Wollenweber and Reinking (1935), Snyder and Hansan (1941, 1945), and Leslie and Summerell (2006). The columns represent these three distinct taxonomic schemes, and the rows show how various sections or species are categorized and related across the different time periods. The classification evolves significantly over time; for example, the 'Eupionnotes' section in the 1935 system corresponds to 'F. episphaeria' in the 1941/1945 system, and is further split into 'F. dimerum' and 'F. merismoides' in the 2006 system. A notable trend is the expansion of categories, where the 'Liseola' section from 1935 is associated with two species in the Snyder and Hansan system but expands to include 'F. proliferatum', 'F. subglutinans', and other species in the 'Gibberella fujikuroi species complex' by 2006. The table also shows reclassifications, such as the 'Elegans' section, which was considered 'F. nivale' but is noted as 'No longer considered Fusarium' in the most recent system. Overall, the table illustrates a progression from broader sectional classifications to a more complex and speciose system for Fusarium over 70 years.

A series of illustrations displays various fungal structures labeled A through Z. The first group shows different forms of macroconidia, including a large, curved, multi-septate example (A) and several smaller variations (B, C, D). Following these are detailed views of different cell shapes, such as rounded (E), beaked (F), hooked (G, H), and other forms (I, J, K, L). A collection of microconidia showcases a variety of shapes: oval (M, N), septate (O), kidney-shaped (P), pear-shaped (Q, R), and spherical (S, T). Conidiophore arrangements are also depicted, ranging from simple structures (U) to those showing budding (V) and branching patterns (W, X). Finally, hyphal structures are shown as simple branching filaments (Y) and a more complex, interconnected network (Z).

The process of DNA replication begins with an original double-stranded DNA molecule, surrounded by nucleotides and DNA primers. In the first step, Denaturation, the original DNA separates into two single strands. The second step is Annealing, where a DNA primer binds to each of the single strands. Finally, in the Extension phase, a new complementary strand is synthesized from the primer along each original strand, creating two new complete double-stranded DNA molecules.

This table lists different Fusarium species and the plant parts they are associated with. The data is structured into categories by plant part, followed by a list of species. The 'root and stem bases' are associated with F. acuminatum, F. avenaceum, F. compactum, F. equiseti, F. proliferatum, F. oxysporum, and F. solani. The 'leaves and aerial parts' are linked to F. proliferatum and F. semitectum. The 'flowers' are associated with F. chlamydosporum, F. equiseti, and F. poae. A category for 'seed and grain' is also listed, but no corresponding species are provided. Overall, the table maps various Fusarium species to specific plant parts, although the information for seed and grain is missing.

The table categorizes different species, likely of the genus Fusarium, based on their geographical distribution across various climate regions. The columns represent three distinct regional classifications: 'All regions', 'Temperate regions', and 'Subtropical and Tropical regions'. The rows list the specific species found in each category. Seven species, including F. chlamydosporum and F. solani, are identified as being present in 'All regions'. A separate list of seven species, such as F. acuminatum and F. graminearum, are specific to 'Temperate regions'. One species in this category, 'NI F. avenaceum', has an unclear 'NI' prefix. The 'Subtropical and Tropical regions' category contains the fewest species listed, with four, including F. beomiforme and F. longipes. Overall, the table provides a classification of Fusarium species by their prevalence in all, temperate, or subtropical/tropical climate zones.

This table provides a detailed morphological analysis of four isolates, all identified as the species F. solani. Each row corresponds to a specific isolate (TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, CHA040), while the columns describe characteristics related to their macroconidia, microconidia, chlamydospores, and colony colors. All four isolates share common traits: their macroconidia are fusiform with blunt-rounded apical shapes, and their microconidia exhibit shapes like oval, ellipsoid, and reniform with 'mono phialides' for the 'false head' characteristic. However, there are key differences. The macroconidia foot shape is 'distinct' for the first three isolates but 'poorly developed' for CHA040. Colony colors also vary: TRA006 is 'purple - dark purple', TRA020 is 'white - dark white', and the remaining two are 'white- cream'. The 'Chlamydospores' column is empty for all isolates. In summary, while all isolates are classified as F. solani with many similar microscopic features, they exhibit distinct variations in colony color and macroconidial foot shape.

text.text_translated:
The visual analysis presents four distinct fungal isolates, each characterized by its colony morphology and microscopic features. The first isolate (A-E) displays a colony with a purplish center and concentric rings from the top view (A) and dark orange-brown pigmentation on the reverse (B). Its microscopic structures include conidiophores (C), elongated and curved macroconidia with pointed apical (ac) and basal (bc) cells (D), and small, oval microconidia (E). The second isolate (F-J) has a whitish-grey colony with concentric rings (F) and a dark brown pigment on the reverse (G), producing conidiophores (H), curved macroconidia (I), and oval microconidia (J). The third isolate (K-O) forms a white, cottony colony (K) with faint brownish pigmentation on the reverse (L), with microscopic features including conidiophores (M), slightly curved macroconidia (N), and oval microconidia (O). The fourth isolate (P-T) shows a pale green colony with a lobed pattern (P) and a light yellowish-brown reverse (Q), producing conidiophores (R), curved macroconidia (S), and small, oval microconidia (T).

This table presents data on the diameter of colonies, measured in centimeters, for four different strains identified as TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040, under various treatment conditions. The rows list the different treatments, such as 'PDA', 'SNA', and 'Kerr's', with some variations including 'carnation leaves'. The columns correspond to the four strains. The table also includes statistical measures like Coefficient of Variation (C.V. %), Least Significant Difference (LSD), and p-values. The data values are followed by letters, which likely indicate statistical groupings. The structure of the table is somewhat unclear, as some data for a single treatment appears to be split across multiple rows, and one row of data lacks a treatment label. Among the readable data, the largest colony diameter recorded is 7.10 cm for strain TRA020 under the 'SNA' treatment. The smallest diameter is 3.21 cm for strain CHA040 under the 'KC1 + carnation leaves' treatment. Adding carnation leaves to the 'Kerr's' treatment resulted in larger colony diameters for all four strains. In conclusion, the table shows that colony diameter varies significantly based on both the treatment medium and the specific strain.

This table displays the number of spores, measured in units of '10%/ml', for four different fungal isolates (TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, CHA040) under various treatment conditions. The rows detail eight different growth media treatments, such as PDA, SNA, and KCl, with and without the addition of carnation leaves. For each combination of isolate and treatment, the table provides separate counts for two types of spores, labeled 'mac' (likely macroconidia) and 'mic' (likely microconidia). For isolate TRA006, the SNA medium produced the highest microconidia count (34.00a), while SNA with carnation leaves produced the highest macroconidia count (5.40a). For isolate TRA020, the PDA medium resulted in the highest counts for both spore types (2.60a and 38.8a, respectively). In contrast, the KC1 and Kerr's media treatments consistently yielded the lowest spore counts across most isolates and spore types. The final rows contain statistical data, including Coefficient of Variation (C.V. %), LSD, and p-values. Overall, the data indicates that spore production is highly dependent on both the specific isolate and the growth medium used, with PDA and SNA media generally being more productive than KC1 and Kerr's media.

Four fungal isolates—TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040—exhibit different growth characteristics across eight experimental conditions labeled A through H. In condition A, colony morphology varies, with TRA006 showing purple pigmentation, while the other isolates are primarily white or grey. Conditions C and E utilize a blue-toned medium, where C supports diffuse mycelial growth and E shows severely restricted growth. On a purple medium (conditions G and H), all isolates produce a distinct central white colony. Several conditions (B, D, F, H) assess growth originating from small colonized blocks placed on the various types of media.

Several conditions (B, D, F, H) assess growth originating from small colonized blocks placed on the various types of media.

This table presents data from 1943 on the spore germination percentages for four different biological isolates. The first column lists the isolate identifiers, along with statistical measures, while the second column provides the corresponding spore germination percentage. Isolate CHA032 exhibited the highest germination rate at 94.23%, closely followed by CHA040 at 92.61%. Isolate TRA006 had a lower rate of 77.53%, while TRA020 had the lowest germination percentage at 53.50%. The table also includes statistical values such as a Coefficient of Variation (C.V.) of 6.57%, a Least Significant Difference (LSD) of 6.99, and a P-value denoted by an asterisk, suggesting the results are statistically significant. Overall, the isolates showed significantly different spore germination rates, with the 'CHA' isolates having the highest values.

Panel B displays a few individual conidia with shorter, unbranched germ tubes. Panel C presents a higher density of conidia at various germination stages, from early budding to longer tube formation. 1943 

The growth of four fungal isolates, labeled TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040, is observed at five different temperatures. At 15°C, all four isolates show minimal growth. Growth increases for all isolates at 20°C. The optimal temperature for most appears to be 25°C, where TRA006, TRA020, and CHA032 show their most extensive colony expansion, with the former two developing visible concentric rings. At 30°C, growth begins to decline for TRA006 and TRA020, while CHA032 and CHA040 maintain substantial growth. At 35°C, the growth of all four isolates is significantly inhibited, resulting in small colonies.

Four fungal strains, TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040, are cultured under three different lighting conditions: 24 hours of continuous light, a 12-hour light/dark cycle, and 24 hours of continuous darkness. The strains TRA006 and TRA020 exhibit distinct concentric rings, which are most pronounced in the 12-hour light/dark cycle. The CHA032 strain shows a more uniform, fluffy growth pattern across all three conditions. The CHA040 strain also displays some zonation, particularly under the light/dark cycle, and its growth appears more diffuse in continuous darkness.

The table presents scientific or experimental data on the effect of pH on several variables. The rows correspond to different pH levels, specifically 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. The columns represent measurements for variables identified by codes such as TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040, with each apparently having two sub-measurements labeled 'mac' and 'mic'. The numerical values in the table are accompanied by letters (a, b, c, d, e), which typically denote statistical groupings. A clear trend emerges where the measured values for most variables peak at a pH of 7. For instance, the 'mic' measurement under CHA032 is 20.10 at pH 7, significantly higher than at other pH levels. Similarly, the 'mic' measurement under CHA040 is 19.10 at pH 7. Values are generally lowest at the pH extremes of 5, 8, and 9. The bottom rows provide statistical context, including the Coefficient of Variation (C.V. %), Least Significant Difference (LSD), and p-values, which are marked as significant ('*') for most columns. The main takeaway is that the measured parameters are highly dependent on pH, with a neutral pH of 7 yielding the highest results across most variables.

The growth of four fungal isolates, labeled TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040, is shown in petri dishes at five different pH levels: 5, 6, 7, 8, and 9. Isolates TRA006 and TRA020 display compact, circular colonies with a dark center and a lighter outer ring, showing relatively consistent size across the pH range. Isolates CHA032 and CHA040 exhibit more diffuse, white, cotton-like growth. The growth of CHA032 appears to be most vigorous around pH 6 and 7, while CHA040 shows its largest colony size at pH 7, with smaller colonies at other pH levels.

This table presents data on disease severity, measured in centimeters (cm), for four different isolates (TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, CHA040) on various plant parts after a specified inoculation period. The rows correspond to the isolates and summary statistics, while the columns detail disease severity for branches (21 days), leaves (7 days), flowers (5 days), and roots (21 days). For branches, disease severity was consistently high across all isolates, ranging from 26.00 to 26.67 cm. In contrast, severity on roots varied significantly: isolate CHA040 caused the most severe disease at 32.00 cm, while TRA020 caused the least at 16.00 cm. The p-values suggest no significant difference among isolates for branches, leaves, and flowers ('ns'), but a significant difference for roots ('*'). The main takeaway is that the isolates caused significantly different levels of disease severity in the roots but had a similar impact on the other plant parts tested.

Hansgnton uyos Fusarium solani inuu 4 'lolran 

The table shows the severity of diseases, measured in centimeters (cm), on different plant parts after specific inoculation periods in days (d). The rows list various isolates (TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, CHA040), though the first two are grouped, followed by statistical metrics. The columns represent plant parts: 'Branches (21d) Leaves (7d)', 'Flowers (5d)', and 'Roots (21d)'. The data for the 'Branches/Leaves' column is presented inconsistently, making direct comparison difficult; for instance, isolate CHA032 has two severity values listed (12.33 and 17.33), while others have one. For 'Flowers', disease severity was low, with the highest value being 1.00 cm for the TRA006/TRA020 group. For 'Roots', the severity was highest, with isolate CHA040 causing the most damage at 30.00 cm, followed by CHA032 at 24.00 cm. The table includes statistical measures like Coefficient of Variation (C.V.), Least Significant Difference (LSD), and indicates significant p-values with asterisks. In summary, isolate CHA040 generally caused the highest disease severity, especially in the roots, while flowers were the least affected part.

column values follow by the same letter are significant different $_ { ( P < 0 . 0 5 ) }$ 

1943 

A series of six panels, labeled A through E, documents the declining health of a plant. Panels A and B show the initial stages, where the plant has young, light-green to yellow leaves at the top and more mature green leaves below. The condition worsens significantly in the subsequent panels. Panel C shows the plant with its leaves wilted, brown, and dry. In panel D, the plant is almost entirely dead, with a bare stem and only a few shriveled leaves remaining. The final stage is depicted in the two panels labeled E, where the plants are completely withered, with all leaves brown, dry, and drooping.

eny 6tneu Iaultesn Fusarium solani inuau 4'lelkan uuuviuna (A-B) control, (C) TRA006, (D) TRA020, (E) CHA032 l (F) CHA040 u nnT nangn!0 21 ju 

A series of six images, labeled A through F, documents the progressive decline of a plant shoot. In stage A, the shoot has several leaves of mixed green and yellowish-bronze color. In stage B, the leaves are uniformly yellow and appear wilted. Stage C shows the plant after it has lost most of its foliage, with only a single green leaf remaining. By stage D, the stem is completely bare. The decline advances in stage E, where the top of the leafless stem begins to wither and bend. The final stage, F, shows the shoot completely dried out and shriveled, with its top severely drooped.

The development of lesions on plant leaves is documented in two series, labeled A-C and D-F. In the first series, an initial leaf is marked with 'w' (wounded) and 'uw' (unwounded) (A). Subsequently, a small, brown lesion develops and expands on the wounded side (B and C). The second series begins with a similarly marked leaf (D). A larger, circular brown lesion with a yellow halo then develops on its wounded side (E), followed by another observation of the lesion (F).

A visual comparison shows the external and internal morphology of clove buds in both healthy and seemingly infected states. A healthy bud, shown whole in panel A and bisected in panel B, has a smooth, green exterior and a well-defined internal structure. In contrast, several other samples display signs of fungal infection. Panels C and D depict a bud heavily covered in a white substance, with its bisected view showing internal discoloration. Similarly, panels E and F, as well as G and H, show buds with external white fungal growth and discolored interiors. The final sample, in panels I and J, also exhibits this external growth, and its bisected view reveals significant internal degradation.

awn 16 ennsnwuuuaennuunannnsgnbeaau Fusarium solani iuu 4 'lolnian 1uNa na1ngn!B0 5 u (A-B) control, (C-D) TRA006, (E-F) TRA020, (G-H) CHA032 l (I-J) CHA040 

A series of images compares healthy and infected flower buds. A healthy control specimen is shown whole (A) and bisected (B), revealing a clean, light-colored interior. In contrast, progressive stages of fungal infection are documented. An early-stage infection (C) displays white mold on the surface, with slight internal discoloration visible in the cross-section (D). More advanced infections (E and G) show increasingly dense white fungal growth on the exterior, corresponding to significant internal browning and decay in the bisected views (F and H). Another infected sample (I) also shows heavy mold, and its internal view (J) likewise displays severe degradation.

A comparison of five plant samples shows varying states of health across three views: the full plant, a close-up of its foliage, and its excavated root system. The 'Control' sample appears healthy with green leaves and a dense root structure. The 'TRA006' sample shows signs of wilting and leaf loss. The 'TRA020' plant exhibits more severe wilting and has very few leaves remaining. The 'CHA032' sample is a bare, dry stem, and its root system appears less extensive. Similarly, the 'CHA040' sample is also a leafless, dry stem with a dark, unhealthy-looking root system.

This table displays colony counts from soil dilution, measured in colony-forming units per gram (cfu/g), for four different treatments (TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, CHA040) over a five-month period. The rows represent measurements at months 1, 3, and 5, along with statistical values like Coefficient of Variation (C.V. %), Least Significant Difference (LSD), and p-value. The columns correspond to the different treatments. The colony count for TRA006 increased steadily from 8.75 to 26.67, although this change was not statistically significant ('ns'). For treatments TRA020 and CHA032, counts rose from around 10-12 to a high of 50.83 and 61.92, respectively, by month 5, a change that was highly significant ('**'). Treatment CHA040 also showed a significant increase ('*'), jumping from 6.25 in month 1 to 33.17 by month 3. Overall, all treatments showed an increase in colony counts over the five months, with the changes for TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040 being statistically significant.

A comparison of colony counts from soil dilution (cfu/g) for four different isolates (TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040) is shown at three time intervals: 1 month, 3 months, and 5 months. For isolate TRA006, the counts increase over time from approximately 8 to 21, and finally to 26 cfu/g. Isolate TRA020 shows a sharp increase at the 5-month mark, rising to about 50 cfu/g from around 12-13 cfu/g in the first two measurements. Isolate CHA032 displays the highest overall count, jumping to approximately 62 cfu/g at 5 months after starting at around 10-15 cfu/g. Isolate CHA040 shows a significant increase between 1 and 3 months, from roughly 6 to 32 cfu/g, and then levels off at about 34 cfu/g at 5 months.

Four petri dishes, labeled A, B, C, and D, display different levels of microbial growth on a purple medium. Dish A shows a dense concentration of large, clumpy, white colonies. Dish B features a moderate number of smaller, scattered white colonies. Dish C has the least growth, with only a few small, well-separated colonies. Dish D presents a high number of very small, scattered white colonies.

text.text:
column values follow by the same letter are significant different $_ { ( \mathrm { P < 0 . 0 5 } ) }$ estimation based on colony counts from soil dilution 

A comparison of colony counts from soil dilution (cfu/g) for four different isolates (TRA006, TRA020, CHA032, and CHA040) is shown at three time intervals: 1 month, 3 months, and 5 months. For isolate TRA006, the counts increase over time from approximately 8 to 21, and finally to 26 cfu/g. Isolate TRA020 shows a sharp increase at the 5-month mark, rising to about 50 cfu/g from around 12-13 cfu/g in the first two measurements. Isolate CHA032 displays the highest overall count, jumping to approximately 62 cfu/g at 5 months after starting at around 10-15 cfu/g. Isolate CHA040 shows a significant increase between 1 and 3 months, from roughly 6 to 32 cfu/g, and then levels off at about 34 cfu/g at 5 months.

A scientific experiment evaluates the effects of a substance at nine different concentrations on six distinct samples, labeled A through F. The concentrations tested, indicated in the bottom row labeled G, range from a 'control' group to 1,500 ppm, with intermediate levels at 62.5, 125, 250, 500, 750, 1,000, and 1,250 ppm. The samples exhibit varied responses to the increasing concentrations. Row D, which has a distinct red medium, shows that the central white fungal growth is progressively inhibited as the concentration rises. Similarly, row F demonstrates a strong inhibitory effect, with the size of the central white fungal colony decreasing significantly as the concentration increases. In contrast, row E displays relatively consistent growth across all conditions. Other rows show different effects: Row A exhibits some growth suppression, row B develops a bluish-green coloration at higher concentrations, and row C shows varied growth patterns of its central colony.

The results of a fungal growth experiment are presented across six series, labeled A through F, each tested at nine different concentrations. The concentrations, indicated by labels in row G, range from a control sample to 1,500 ppm, with intermediate steps at 62.5, 125, 250, 500, 750, 1,000, and 1,250 ppm. Across most series, an increase in concentration generally corresponds to a decrease in the diameter of the fungal colony, suggesting an inhibitory effect. Specific series exhibit distinct characteristics: series B shows the development of a bluish-green coloration in the medium at higher concentrations, while series D is characterized by a prominent red-purple pigment surrounding the colonies.

The experimental results show the growth of six different microbial cultures, labeled A through F, in Petri dishes under varying concentrations of a test substance. The concentrations, ranging from a 'control' with no substance up to 1,500 ppm, are applied across nine columns. In row A, the culture displays dark growth that is minimally affected by the increasing concentrations. Row B shows a light-colored, fuzzy culture whose growth is visibly inhibited at higher concentrations, with some dishes developing a greenish tint. The cultures in row C and row F, both featuring distinct white central growth, demonstrate a strong dose-dependent response, with growth size decreasing significantly as the concentration of the substance increases. Row D exhibits a culture producing a red pigment, which appears relatively resistant to the substance across the tested concentrations. Finally, the off-white, fuzzy culture in row E shows slight inhibition of growth at higher concentrations.

This table presents the results of an experiment comparing the effects of different treatments on disease incidence and severity. The data lists several treatments, including a negative control, a positive control, and three chemical agents (carbendazim, hymaxazol, pyraclostrobin), alongside their corresponding 'Disease Incidence (%)' and 'Disease Severity (cm)'. The 'negative control' showed no disease (0% incidence, 0.00 cm severity), while the 'positive control' exhibited the highest levels of disease (75% incidence, 7.12 cm severity). Among the chemical treatments, 'carbendazim 500 ppm' was the most effective, with an incidence of 31% and severity of 2.04 cm. 'Hymaxazol 540 ppm' and 'pyraclostrobin 125 ppm' showed intermediate results. The table also includes statistical metrics: a Coefficient of Variation (C.V.) of 50.41%, a Least Significant Difference (LSD) of 3.16, and a significant p-value indicated by an asterisk. Overall, the data suggests that while all chemical treatments reduced disease compared to the positive control, carbendazim was the most effective.
